greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Exponential abundant numbers: integers n for which A126164(n)>n, or equivalently for which A051377(n)>2n.
comment: There are only 52189 exponential abundant numbers less than 50 million, which suggests that these account for approximately 0.1% of all integers.
Includes 36*m for all m coprime to 6 that are not squarefree. - _Robert Israel_, Feb 19 2019
reference: Hagis, Peter Jr.; Some Results Concerning Exponential Divisors, Internat. J. Math. & Math. Sci., Vol. 11, No. 2, (1988), pp. 343-350.
link: Robert Israel, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
example: The third integer that is exceeded by its proper exponential divisor sum is 3600. Hence a(3)=3600.
results.author: _Ant King_, Apr 28 2007
